newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Pakistan using donated mlns to repay foreign debt.
newsitem.headline: Pakistan using donated mlns to repay foreign debt.

text.p: The State (central) Bank of Pakistan (SBP) said on Monday it was using $210 million, collected from the public after an appeal by Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, to repay foreign debt.
Sharif launched his National Debt Retirement Programme (NDRP) to raise money in the form of donations and deposits after winning power in February elections.
"Foreign currency deposits amounting to about $210 million received up to June 26, 1997 under the NDRP are being used in the repayment of foreign debt," the SBP said in a statement.
On Friday, the SBP said it had used 1.5 billion rupees from privatisation of a state-owned bank to retire domestic debt.

The proceeds from this month's sale of a 70 percent stake in Habib Credit and Exchange Bank Ltd were used to retire debt totalling 1.5 billion rupees which carried an interest rate of 17.29 percent a year.
The SBP also said it had used a donation of 1.7 billion rupees it had received from an undisclosed source to retire domestic debt carrying the same interest rate.
"Accordingly, since June 27, 1997, a total of 3.2 billion rupees of the most expensive debt has been retired," it said.
Pakistan's domestic debt will total one trillion (1,000 billion) rupees at the end of fiscal 1996/97 (July-June) according to budget estimates.
